messages.title: Stronger Economy. Fairer Society. Opportunity for Everyone.
messages.content: He knows this will be the most important general election for many years — a time to vote wisely.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: The economy recovering whilst long-term (beyond 2020) Conservative service cuts vigorously opposed.
Schools have been supported with dedicated per-pupil funding.
Thousands of new apprenticeships created; re-training in work available for all ages.
The environment safeguarded with farming – e.g. milk prices – recognised as troubled by a committee chaired by Tim Farron MP.
New rail electrification due in Cumbria with prospects of a 'Waverley route' re-opening (Longtown).
Realistic funding plans for NHS put in place, retaining community hospitals and encompassing elderly needs.
Fairer pensions – state and private – with the Liberal Democrats' unique 'triple lock' guaranteeing these keep up with inflation.

mentions.candidate: With an educational, but additional part-farming background, Neil Hughes sat on the Penrith Partnership and the board of Eden Housing Association for many years. He is currently the lay member on Eden’s NHS Clinical Commissioning Body and an active member of the rural and farming network for the county.
mentions.otherPartyLeaderCandidate: Conservative - deep service cuts. Labour - leads us there with the cuts to benefits. UKIP - all kinds of things but deliver little.

issues.brexitEurope: CONSERVATIVE - Anti-European with insidious support to fracking. LABOUR - Remember 2008? UKIP - anti-everything.

housing.content: Neil says: 'I am aware that ours is an area into which older people wish to move and which young people tend to leave. Penrith & the Border – with its pleasant rural surroundings – has the capability to attract new business, bringing in skills and justifying training for our currently young people too. Lib Dems such as myself have the guts to wish to improve public transport to bus further homes into the available town centre. The Tory government wouldn't allow this. We need new homes too – sensitively designed and located but also affordable for those who want to stay here.'

leaflet.personalStatement: Neil's personal statement may be inferred from the mention: 'With an educational, but additional part-farming background, Neil Hughes sat on the Penrith Partnership and the board of Eden Housing Association for many years. He is currently the lay member on Eden’s NHS Clinical Commissioning Body and an active member of the rural and farming network for the county.'

politicalExperience.achievements: Neil stood for Carlisle in 2010 improving the party’s vote there and has served on the Eden area as a District and County Councillor throughout recent difficult times.
